latest news.eng_title: When EV startups shut down, will their cars still work?
latest news.summary: When WM Motor, a Chinese electric vehicle startup, filed for bankruptcy in October 2023, its owners encountered issues with their vehicles going 'offline.' Richard Qian, a WM Motor owner, discovered that he could no longer log into the company's smartphone app, which remotely controlled the car lock and air conditioner, and couldn't see his car's mileage and charging status on the dashboard. This is a concern for many Chinese EV owners, as their cars rely heavily on cloud services, including smartphone controls and software updates. With over 100 Chinese EV manufacturers struggling for survival, an estimated 160,000 car owners are left in the lurch, worried about their access to factory parts in future repairs. Lei Xing, an EV analyst, said, 'The biggest concern [for EV owners] is battery degradation, and secondly the operability and stability of the software.' The Chinese government is trying to boost the EV sector with new consumer incentives, but investors are warning that many EV startups will struggle to stay afloat. 'Many will be under pressure for sure, but we're unlikely to see announcements of 'We're done,' said Xing. 'It's a slow-death process.'
latest news.title: When EV startups shut down, will their cars still work?

latest news.eng_title: Small businesses are losing a lifeline as Tampa Bay bankruptcies surge
latest news.summary: The recent sunset of pandemic-era legislative changes has eliminated a more cost-effective alternative for small business reorganizations in Tampa Bay. The debt-eligibility limit for small businesses to file under Subchapter V of the U.S. bankruptcy code has reverted from $7.5 million to $3 million, forcing more small businesses to reorganize through the more costly and lengthy traditional Chapter 11 process. According to Trenam bankruptcy attorney Stephanie Lieb, 'A lot of people in our industry — bankruptcy lawyers and judges — hoped that the higher debt limit would be permanent.' Lieb expects the upward trend in small business bankruptcy filings to continue, citing the end of deferrals and workout agreements for loans created during the pandemic as a major contributor. She noted, 'The only wild card for me is the election and the [Federal Reserve]. The Fed is expected to lower interest rates next month. That could bring some relief, but it's hard to say if they will come through with a reduction and, if so, what size or whether it will have a material effect.'
latest news.title: Small businesses are losing a lifeline as Tampa Bay bankruptcies surge

latest news.eng_title: Americans to get one-time payment from $1.8m surcharge settlement – but you must fill out an online form to get cash
latest news.summary: Some Americans may be eligible for a one-time payment from a $1.8 million class action settlement with RealPage Utility Management. The company is paying out to settle claims that it charged an unlawful administration fee to Maryland residents. To qualify, individuals must have been a Maryland customer who received a charge from RealPage between April 1, 2017 and June 30, 2023. The amount of the payment will depend on how much was charged, and about one third of the settlement will go towards lawyers. The deadline to file a claim is September 2, and payments will be made after that. 'It's not yet clear when payments will go out,' according to the article. 'It's too late to opt out of the case, meaning your rights can be impacted even if you don't file a claim.'

latest news.eng_title: EV maker Fisker to be liquidated under plan to keep owners on the road
latest news.summary: Fisker Inc., a troubled electric vehicle maker, has reached a settlement with creditors to liquidate its assets while working with owners to keep their SUVs on the road. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June after failing to reach a strategic agreement with another automaker. The settlement allows Fisker management to remain in charge for some time as the operation winds down. Fisker's owners association will have a voice in the sale of the company's intellectual property, including designs and computer code necessary to build and operate the vehicles. However, shareholders who invested in Fisker are unlikely to get their money back, with secured and unsecured claims against the company likely to top $1 billion. 'It's a virtual certainty that there will be no money for equity. There's no way you're going to have enough to pay claims in full in this liquidation,' said David Golubchik, a veteran bankruptcy attorney. Fisker's chairman and CEO, Henrik Fisker, and his wife, Geeta Gupta-Fisker, received bonuses in December of a little more than $1 million each, which were disclosed in a bankruptcy court filing. 'As a shareholder and a car owner who had supported Henrik and his wife, I am seeing red,' said Evan Scott, who owns a Fisker Ocean and figures he lost about $50,000 on the company's stock. 'They knew the company was in dire straits. They were just expediting bankruptcy by doing that.'
latest news.title: EV maker Fisker to be liquidated under plan to keep owners on the road
